title: aussie-rugby-player-caring-galashiels-lockdown
story: A KIND-HEARTED Australian rugby player has been delivering food to elderly folk in the Borders town he currently calls home.Gala RFC forward Cody Roman, , moved from Wollongong, New South Wales, in October last year.When coronavirus put paid to his plans to explore more of the Borders, he decided to channel his free time into volunteering as a driver with Food Train.He said: ldquoIrsquom fortunate that Irsquom mobile so I want to get out and help those who are less fortunate or in need."For six weeks, Cody has been dropping off food to residents who are self-isolating.He said: ldquoIt got to the end of winter and I was looking forward to seeing some nice summer days, and then this [lockdown] happened.ldquoThe club put a post on social media askingthere were any guys ready to help out with anything, like shopping or dog-walking or anything that people were unable to do now, for people who had to self-isolate.ldquoThe Food Train commented on the post, and I was like, lsquoIrsquoll do itrsquo. And Irsquove being doing it for six weeks now.ldquoItrsquos been really good ndash everyone appreciates it. Some people who live alone might not have seen anyone for a few days, so theyrsquore very happy when we come out to them and have a chat.ldquoSome of them are very excited and grateful. Some of them offer us a cup of tea and we have to let them down easy."Despite being so far from his home Down Under, Cody is coping well with the coronavirus lockdown.ldquoItrsquos not too bad, with Facebook and social media and stuff. I can just send messages and give people a call."And Irsquom pretty fortunate where I live ndash everyonersquos very friendly.

title: ex-lauder-footballer-toasts-50th-anniversary-cup-win
story: A REUNION to mark the th anniversary of Lauder Amateur FC clinching the South of Scotland Cup has been cancelled due to coronavirus.Lauder triumphed - over Tweeddale Rovers at Netherdale, Galashiels, on May , .Members of the successful side had been planning to meet up this summer, but COVID- has put paid to the proposal.George Threadgall, , told the Border that he still treasures memories of Lauderrsquos achievement.ldquoIt was like the European Cup for us, said the former defender, adding: ldquoI think half of Lauder was there that night.Led by coaches Jim Brotherston and Alex McDonald, Lauder went down - through an own goal, recalled Mr Threadgall, before roaring back to put their noses in front.After Rovers hoofed a penalty kick over the bar in the dying minutes, Mr Threadgall and team-mates celebrated a famous victory when they arrived home.ldquoYou go to Lauder and mention the South team and locals will bore you to tears about how big a thing it was for the town, said Mr Threadgall, a retired engineer living in Linlithgow.Lauderrsquos goals came courtesy of forwards Jimmy Gillie and Stan Seaton, said Mr Threadgall, with centre-half Kenny Rutherford being the unfortunate player who turned the ball into his own net.The reunion had been planned for late July or early August in Lauderrsquos Golden Bannock pub, said Mr Threadgall.Guests would have included Dave Elrick, now living in South Africa, who was Lauder Cornet in the year he helped his hometown side to the cup.Mr Threadgall, a grandfather, was himself Lauder Cornet in .

title: uk-government-refuses-share-galashiels-virus-results
story: THE UK Government has refused to sendstatistics to the Border relating to coronavirus tests carried out in Galashiels this month.The army ran a temporary testing facilityfor self-isolating key workers and their relatives at the Netherdale car park in the first week of May.But a UK Government spokesperson told this newspaper that the number of people seen at ldquoinidual test sites would not be disclosed.A follow-up request for further details on the Netherdale centre was also turned down this week.Details included whether an extension had been granted.The pop-up facility was one of dozens set up earlier this month as part of the UK Governments push for more testing. The Borders centre was scheduled to run between May  and May .Self-isolating key workers with symptoms were eligible for tests, as were their relatives living under the same roof.These are the questions which the Border posed to the UK Government on May :How many people have visited the Galashiels testing centre so far How many of those have received a positive diagnosis for the virus How do the number of visitors to the site in Galashiels compare to those in other mobile centres established in Scotland How do the number of positive cases confirmed at the Galashiels site compare to other centres in Scotland What further advice treatment is offered to those who test positive at a drive through centre Will the government extend theof time the town has this mobile testing facility beyond May  As the sites are only open to those showing signs of the virus or who are living with someone with symptoms, what is the purpose of these tests

title: furlough-extended-october-questions-answered
story: Chancellor Rishi Sunak has saidthe UK Governmentrsquos furlough scheme willbe extended until the end of October.But what does it all mean for workers and businesses Heres what you need to know.What will happen to workers on furlough Mr Sunak said they will continue to receive  per centof their pay ndash up to pound, a month ndash until the end of October.This extends the original furlough scheme to eight months since it was launched in March.The Chancellor also said there will be the possibility of part-time s for staff from August, pointing out that manufacturers have been asking for staggered shts to reopen production lines.Are there more details on part-time s and can I take a job where The details will be published later this month, but Mr Sunak stressed to MPs that furloughed workers can take jobs where while on the scheme.Government advice says: ldquoIf your contract allows, you may undertake other employment while your current employer has placed you on furlough, and this will not affect the grant that they can claim under the scheme.However, staff cannot work for their employer while furloughed.Will the Government continue covering the cost The Government will fund the furlough scheme, which has supported seven million jobs at a cost of pound billion a month, until the end of July.After that, companies will be expected to make a contribution to the payments, although the amount workers take home will not fall below the  per cent mark.How much will businesses be expected to pay towards furlough The details will be published later this month, the Chancellor said, but it is likely to be judged on a sector-by-sector basis, similar to the details published on Monday by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategyfor companies looking to reopen under new ldquoCovid Secure measures.With certain sectors ing to some normality, others, including restaurants and gyms, remain unlikely to reopen fully for several months.Can we expect to see furlough extended beyond October The Government has said it will continue to monitor the situation and is willing to adjust advice accordingly.But Mr Sunak made clear it is unlikely to be extended.He told the Commons: ldquoWe will keep everything under review but my expectation is by thenthe scheme should end. Wersquove stretched and strained to be as generous as possible to businesses and workers, which is why we have made the decision that wersquove made today.The Chancellor added: ldquoBut hellip this scheme is expensive. Itrsquos the right thing to do. The cost of not acting would have been far higher but itrsquos not something that can continue indefinitely into the future. Eight months of total support is a considerable amount of time.Are there any other signicant changes to the furlough scheme More details will come this month, but MPs raised concerns from self-employed workers who pay themselves via idends, asking whether they would be able to receive further support.However, Mr Sunak insisted current support is strong enough.Why is the Government announcing the extension now Under employment laws, companies must start informing any staff they plan to make redundant within  days of any changes.The previous furlough scheme was due to end by July, meaning consultations would need to begin imminently, but the extension to October will address it.

title: borders-actor-jack-lowden-narrates-bbc-football-documentary
story: BORDERS actor Jack Lowden contributed to a BBC documentary aired across Scotland last night .The former Earlston High School pupil narrated Return to Real Kashmir FCabout a Scottish football managers job in Asia.The BBC Scotland show was a sequel to an earlier programme documenting Davie Robertsons first season in charge.Lowden, , narrated the story of Robertsonsto the disputed Himalayan region.In Robertsons playing career, he racked up more than  appearances for both Aberdeen and Rangers, following up with spells at Leeds United and Montrose.

title: let-borders-garden-centres-open-soon-says-msp
story: BORDERS residents should be allowed to visit garden centres soon, according to a politician.Christine Grahame MSP has asked the Scottish Government to consider re-opening such businesses with safety measures in place.Ms Grahame, of the SNP, highlighted the "physical and mental wellbeing benefits" of gardening.The member for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale addressed Holyroods rural economy and connectivity committee this morning.She said: ldquoAny re-opening of businesses of course needs to be done in a safe manner, giving proper consideration to the safety of both staff and the public."Irsquom optimistic that this may be possible with garden centres soon, given the physical and mental wellbeing benefits gardening can offer for us all in lockdown.ldquoIf yoursquore fortunate enough to have access to a garden it can make a real dference and being able to buy some supplies for it could be a real boost to many. Indeed even a window box can make a dference. While you can currently buy online, it is not as satisfactory.ldquoOur horticultural sector has been hit hard by lockdown, with many businesses losing out on what would be one of their busiest periods of trade in spring and early summer."This not only affects the big well known chains, but smaller local businesses and growers.ldquoI welcome news that this is being given serious consideration and I trust the Scottish Government will authorise re-opening soon."

title: john-lamont-cancels-summer-tour-first-time-14-years
story: A BORDERS politician has announced he is cancelling his summer surgery tour for the first time in more than a decade.John Lamont MP and Rachael Hamilton MSP, both Conservatives, had been due to visit  towns and villages over the summer.But with coronavirus restrictions in place, the pair are scrapping their plans.Mr Lamont, who formerly held Ms Hamiltons Holyrood seat, expressed sadness that he would be missing an annual "highlight" for himself.He said: "Irsquom really disappointed that for the first time in  years, it will not be happening this summer."The member for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk ndash who won his first parliamentary election in  ndash said it is important to follow government advice aimed at limiting the spread of COVID-.He added that he continues to hold surgeries over the phone.Ms Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire in the Scottish Parliament, said she is also "disappointed" about the tour cancellation.She added: "I am very much looking forward to meeting constituents again in hopefully the near future when the restrictions are safely lted."

title: borders-businessman-making-living-unwanted-trees
story: AN ENTREPRENEUR is enjoying success by helping to make houses, animal shavings and food pallets.Douglas Mathison, , of Peeblesshire, fells trees across the south of Scotland through his company Agrorest.ldquoEven with the poorest quality timber, you can still get a lot of use out of it, says Mr Mathison, explaining that unwanted woods on farms and estates have the potential to serve a iety of purposes.Once the timber has been taken to the sawmill, Mr Mathison says, the best of it gets transformed into timber-framed houses, while the scraps might ultimately line a rabbit hutch.When Agrorest was founded in , it served a role that was ldquounique in the south of Scotland, according to Mr Mathison.Established firms often shunned the type of tasks that Agrorest expressed an interest in, he says.ldquoWhen I first started, we were the only one in the south of Scotland that was doing this work on a very small basis, Mr Mathison says.ldquoWersquove been taking on an increasing workload, focusing on smaller jobs that other companies are not interested in working on.Although there are now three or four other firms carrying out a similar role in the region, according to Mr Mathison, Agrorest continues to field enquiries from Kilmarnock to West Linton and beyond.Explaining the typical process, Mr Mathison says an initial phone call will often lead to a site visit, which in turn results in Mr Mathison estimating the potential financialthat could be made on a patch of woodlandfelled.If the farmer wishes to press ahead and Mr Mathison secures a licence from Scottish Forestry, Agrorest will send in the machinery, remove the trees and take the timber to sawmills.The farmer can be paid within a few weeks, according to Mr Mathison, who shares a portion of the money he receives from the mills.Aside from felling, Agrorest carries out replanting and also manages a number of estates.Mr Mathison says his success has overcome a historical perception among certain landowners that woodland is ldquonot worth bothering about.In his experience, he says, an undermanaged patch of trees will be worthy of attention ldquonine times out of .Mr Mathison is a former Peebles High School pupil who went on to study rural business management in Edinburgh.He launched Agrorest after a stint working for a large timber harvesting company.

title: 22m-coronavirus-support-approved-borders-businesses
story: MORE than pound million in coronavirus support has been approved for Borders businesses.Scottish Borders Councilhas been managing a portion of the Scottish Governmentrsquos Business Support Fund.More than , payments have now been processed, according to the local authority, amounting to a total of pound. million.Two forms of one-off help are available ndash a pound, grant and a pound, grant, with dfering eligibility criteria.Application forms can be accessed here.

title: 2-000-payments-approved-self-employed-people-borders
story: SELF-EMPLOYED people in the Borders have started receiving money from the council in the form of coronavirus support.The Newly Self-Employed Hardship Fund was launched on May .Since then,  people have been approved for a one-off payment of pound,, according to Scottish Borders Council.The money has been made available by the Scottish Government, with people eligible to applythey set up in business on or after April , .

title: golfers-raise-10-000-peebles-golf-club
story: GOLFERS have donated more than pound, to help Peebles Golf Club while the course is closed.The clubs fundraising drive, launched after the coronavirus lockdown, collected more than pound, last month.Les Biscomb, of the clubs sponsorship sub-committee, hailed the generosity of donors.Reflecting on the campaign so far, he said: ldquoItrsquos been a tremendous success."Unlike golf clubs south of the border, Scottish courses remain closed ndash meaning clubhouse coffers continue to struggle.But the idea of setting up a fundraiser in Peebles has already been vindicated, according to Mr Biscomb.He said: "As a team, we came up with the idea of, while wersquore in lockdown, our members might have vastly reduced income ndash theyrsquore being paid to work at home or are pensioners ndash but therersquos nowhere to spend your money at the moment."You canrsquot go to golf, you canrsquot go down the pub, you canrsquot go to restaurants, many people arenrsquot driving anywhere, so we thought, while wersquore in lockdown, why donrsquot we ask the members in Peebles, who are kindhearted and generous, to put something each month towards a crowdfunder.Comments by donors on the website include, Have my coffee money for the coming month otherwise Irsquoll probably fritter it away and Glad to donate again to ensure our club survives.The sub-committee originally set a target of pound, each month, but received more than pound, in April.Mr Biscomb said: ldquoWe would have been delightedwersquod raised the pound, but in the very first month alone we got to pound,."Some of those were one-offs, so people just wanted to join in with the giving and the spirit of helping the club but even so,you look at May, wersquore already at pound,.ldquoWe were hoping for this to continue for two or three months, pound, a month, just to add in the coffers."This isnrsquot funding thatrsquos needed immediately ndash from a cash perspective, Peebles is doing well."This is really for the quiet periods. Once we turn the corner into next year, thatrsquos really when we might need this money, in the quieter days.ldquoBut who knows whatrsquos going to happen with lockdown, and when wersquore going to get cash back through other means, like the bar and catering, and visitors.Currently, all club staff are on furlough, with the exception of head greenkeeper Steve Borthwick.ldquoSteversquos going a fantastic job, said Mr Biscomb. "The course is in magnicent condition ndash it is very tempting to get out there.Meanwhile, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has announced that golf clubs in England can re-open, as long as social distancing guidelines are followed.Mr Biscomb conceded he is "quite jealous", but indicated he is satisfied with the Scottish rules.He said: ldquoIrsquod love to get out on the golf course. But equally, we understand that the Scottish Government is not ready because the stats are not there."Theyrsquore not comfortable with opening golf clubs and we have to respect that."Hopefully, in a few weeksrsquo time,the number [of virus cases] comes down, we can start to get out in ones and twos."For now, we have to live with it and be sensible."Wersquore in the eighth week already ndash another couple of weeks wonrsquot do any harm."Itrsquos achievable to be sensible for another few weeks.Donations to Peebles Golf Club can be made via: www.justgiving crowdfunding pgcmembersappealfund

title: mountain-bikers-told-ride-within-limits-lockdown
story: MOUNTAIN bikers have been issued with guidance during lockdown.Scottish Cyclinghas outlined a series of dos and donts following the Scottish Governments go-ahead for people to exercise more than once a day.There are four rules cyclists and mountain bikers must adhere to under the new SC guidelines:Only ride from your home ndash it is not essential travel to go mountain biking or cycling and you may face enquiries from the policeyou are stopped en route or ing from a ride. All Forestry and Land Scotland car parks and trails, including the stanes sites, remain closedDo not go far ndash whilst you can go exercise for longer, we recommend riding close to where you live and not into remote areas ndash think more smaller loops rather than one longer remote rideRide well within your limits ndash only ride on trails that are that you are very confident you will be able to ride safely and within your competency. It is highly unlikely that mountain rescue are back to full operations ndash consider the fact that a full rescue may not be possible and may take longer to get to youOnly cycle with members of your own household - keep a safe distance when passing other cyclists or pedestrians.Mountain biking trails such as the stanes at Glentress, Peebles, and Innerleithen are closed until further notice to restrict travel to the trails and for safety as they are not being maintained as they were before lockdown.However, walking trails owned by Forestry and Land Scotland are open to members of the public who can access them without using transport.

title: subway-store-galashiels-busy-since-re-opening
story: SUBWAY in Galashiels has re-opened for takeaway and delivery.The sandwich store, which had closed due to coronavirus restrictions, welcomed customers back this week.The Channel Street premises opened its doors again on Monday , applying social distancing guidance and using protective gear.Store supervisor Imran Han said the shop has been "busy".

title: borders-lib-dems-select-ettrick-roxburgh-berwickshire-candidate
story: THE Liberal Democrats have selected a candidate for next years Holyrood election.Jenny Marr will stand for the Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire constituency ndash currently held by Conservative Rachael Hamilton.The former Selkirk High pupil said: "Irsquom thrilled to have been chosen to represent Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire for the Scottish Liberal Democrats."We are living in extraordinary times and I have been blown away by how communities across the Borders have rallied to support each other."The most important thing we can do as politicians and political parties is to provide assistance to anyone that needs it, learn from our experiences and work to address inequalities which have manest."The vote is set to take place on Thursday, May  of next year.

title: borders-based-msp-introduces-online-advice-surgeries
story: A BORDERS-BASED MSP is introducing video surgeries for his constituents.Paul Wheelhouse, who represents the South of Scotland, has had to temporarily close his Hawick office due to the coronavirus outbreak.But from next Friday, Borderers will be able to have a face-to-face meeting ndash without leaving their homes.Mr Wheelhouse said: "Video advice surgeries will be secure and confidential. Constituents will be able to talk to me as though we were sitting down together in person."I fully appreciate that many people do not have video-conferencing technology, or do not even have the internet in their home. For those people, my office is still contactable by telephone at this time."The online advice surgeries are to complement, not replace, other forms of communication. I would strongly encourage anyone who needs my support to get in touch, either by email or phone, and myself and my team will assist in any way we can."Mr Wheelhousersquos first online surgery will take place from pm on Friday, May .To make an appointment, email: paul.wheelhouse.msp@parliament.scot

title: 75-students-without-laptop-get-device-borders-college
story: BORDERS College has loaned laptops to  students who did not have regular access to a suitable device at home.With face-to-face classes cancelled due to coronavirus restrictions, learning has been taking place remotely.Student who did not have adequate laptops of their own have been allowed to borrow from the Galashiels campus.Sport and exercise student Harrison Dixon, from Earlston, said he was "delighted" with the scheme.He said: ldquoMy personal computer is old and struggling to work with some of the new applications and online resources that we are now using, so I spoke with my course tutor who made me aware of the loan scheme, and I was delighted when it was delivered last week."Having the laptop will allow me to continue with my studies remotely.The college says it has loaned a total of  laptops, including those allocated through its bursary programme.Head of IT Scott Moncrieff said: ldquoBefore the college closed, we were able to prepare and distribute  laptops to students for use."Since lockdown, we have had an additional  requests, which we have been able to fulfil.ldquoAny students who find themselves in the situation that continuing their education is not possible, because they donrsquot have an appropriate device, should contact their course tutor or achievement coach, and they will make the appropriate arrangements.

title: historic-borders-houses-feature-visitscotland-campaign
story: HISTORIC homes in the Borders are featuring in a social media campaign by VisitScotland.The tourist organisation has launched #AWindowOnScotland, which asks people to take a photo from their window.Traquair House, Peeblesshire, is among the stately homes in the Borders taking part, with views from the th century Aikwood Tower, near Selkirk, also being shared across social media.Gillian Steele, chairwoman of Big Houses in the Scottish Borders, said: "I donrsquot think people will necessarily forget we are here, but with us all looking out of our windows dreaming of that day when we can travel again, and indulge our passion for Scottish heritage, this campaign strikes a chord."VisitScotlandrsquos #AWindowOnScotland campaign provides us with a great visual opportunity to continue to promote our Houses, their gardens and their wildle from the same perspective as everyone at home."Irsquom encouraging all the Big Houses to take part, and I hope between the eleven of us we will give visitors a reminder of how beautul our Houses and gardens look this month."The campaigns hashtag has been used , times, with towns and villages across the Borders taking part.Historic buildings participating include Thirlestane Castle, near Lauder, and Mellerstain House, near Kelso.VisitScotlands regional leadership director Paula Ward said: ldquoWersquore thrilled at the reaction to #AWindowOnScotland from residents across the Scottish Borders and heartened that businesses are engaging with the campaign and using the opportunity to share their windows on Scotland with the world during this challenging time.ldquoThe staycation market will be a key driver in the countryrsquos economic recovery and the many wonderful views people have been sharing while they stay at home will surely be an incentive for many to travel when the time comes.ldquoThe campaign is far from over and wersquod encourage residents and businesses to continue posting their views, however they may look, as it is all Scotland, to help lt the spirits of those at home and abroad.To join the campaign, take a photo of a view from your window and share it online using #AWindowOnScotland, then tag your location.

title: national-express-plans-resume-coach-services-july-1
story: National Express has started selling UK coach tickets as it plans to restart services on July .The tickets will be available for a "core coach network" andwill focus on large and medium-sized towns and cities.Revenue dropped about  per cent in April compared withthe same month last year, National Express revealed, as the Government advised Britons to keep away from public transport.Nevertheless, Ebitdawas positive and slightly ahead of expectations as National Express slashed costs by about pound million.What hasNational Express said In a statement to customers, National Express said: "We have extended the temporary suspension of our coach services."A restricted timetable is currently scheduled to resume from Wednesday, July , ."Please note, however, all services are subject to change depending on Government advice."For thosethat have an upcoming journey booked with us on or before June ,  and would like to amend your booking, you can do so for free, for travel any time in the next  months."There is no need to contact us straight away, just completeour ticket amendment formbefore your original outward journey and get back in touch with us when yoursquore ready to travel again."If you do not wish to amend your ticket to another date, we will provide a full refund. If you havenrsquot already done so, please completeour refund formand we will process your refund within  days."Please stay safe and well and, when the time is right, we look forward to welcoming you back on board."Where does National Express travel to The company runs coach services across the UK, including Manchester to Coventry, London to Worthing, Newcastle via Darlington to London, Liverpool to Leeds, Edinburgh and Glasgow to London, plus Bradford to London.

title: graphic-designer-reveals-inspired-borders-kids
story: A GRAPHIC designer is helping to keep families entertained during lockdown after creating free colouring packs.Kate Pearson, , who owns K Graphic Design, has created six art packs to help ease the boredom of being stuck indoors.Kate, of Peebles, said: "I absolutely love my job because I get to be creative every day."Each pack features dferent activities for children ndash and adults ndash including colouring, design, and games like word searches.Kate said: "Just before lockdown, I spoke to the pupils at my old primary school, Priorsford Primary School, about my career."I left feeling inspired by their enthusiasm and the idea of activity packs was born."She had planned to print the packs but wanted them to be accessible so made them digital ndash a decision which has paid off.The downloads page on her website has been visited more than , times in the last two months, she said.Kate ensured that each pack had something for everyone, with themes including rainbows and dinosaurs."They were designed with young people in mind, but have proved to be just as popular with adults ndash especially the dinosaur one," said Kate.Kate also owns Glass Bulldog Wedding Stationary, and with wedding fairs for  cancelled or postponed, both sides of her business have taken a knock."Ninety per cent of my bookings have been cancelled or postponed until next year ndash many of my suppliers are affected too," said Kate."I really feel for all businesses facing closure and couples postponing their weddings."Like everyone, the biggest challenge of COVID- is not seeing friends and family, but staying at home is such a small price to pay to stay safe ndash especially now lsquoNeighboursrsquo is back on five days a week!"Kate ed to Peebles only a few years ago, after enjoying multiple career roles including as a wedding planner and working for a London-based design agency.Looking to the future, Kate already has three new packs in mind and hopes to eventually print the activity books.She also hopes that once the Borders s to normal, many of her usual services will be back up and running, especially those catered for weddings and events."My clients range from small local start-ups to The Botanic Gardens and Amazon ndash no two days are the same," she said."Going freelance also means I can take my dog, Dr Frankenstein, to work. What more could you ask for "

title: tesco-clubcard-vouchers-set-expire-extended-november-2020
story: A BATCH of Tesco Clubcard vouchershave been extended by the supermarket.The extension comes as Tesco says customers across the UK have not been shopping as frequently as before the lockdown period began in March.Herersquos everything you need to know.Changing shopping habitsWith some customers unable to visit stores at all during lockdown, and others visiting less frequently, shopping habits have changed over the past few months.Tesco has reported that visits to the supermarket have halved since lockdown, but basket sizes have doubled.Clubcard vouchers extendedHowever, those with Clubcard vouchers could now be struggling to spend them before they expire,they cannot get to a store or book a delivery slot.Tesco has therefore issued a statement to shoppers stating that Clubcard points that were due to expire this month will now be extended, Manchester Evening News reports.Zoe Evans, of Tescos customer engagement centre, said:"We appreciate that, for many reasons, most of us arenrsquot shopping as often as we did before lockdown."As a little help from Clubcard, we want to give you more time to use your vouchers which were due to expire on May , ."Any vouchers issued in May  will now not expire until November , , giving you an extra six months to use them."Well update the expiry date on your digital vouchers, and well continue to accept paper vouchers in-store until the extended expiry date. We really hope it helps, and take care."

title: line-duty-shutdown-due-covid-19-massive-blow---vicky-mcclure
story: Line Of Duty star Vicky McClure has said it was a ldquomassive blow when the show was forced to shut down due to coronavirus and she is keen to resume filming as soon as possible.McClure told the BBCrsquos Andrew Marr Show that filming will only restart when it is safe to do so, as she said that it is dficult for anybody, regardless of their business to not be able to go to work ldquowhen that is what we naturally do.The actress said: ldquoIt was strange because we were on set and a lot was unfolding.ldquoI think we all knew we were not far off having to shut down. And we did when it was the right time to do it.ldquoItrsquos a massive blow for everybody, no matter what business yoursquore in, itrsquos tough to not have to go to work when thatrsquos what we naturally do.Asked by Marrshe is ldquoraring to get back, McClure said: ldquoYes, of course. title: pupils-ve-day-film-premieres-online-due-coronavirus
story: The film was made by the schoolrsquos film club, named Peely-wally Productions, in collaboration with Longniddry Parish Church, before lockdown began in March.The pupils planned, shot and edited the film as part of the th anniversary of VE Day.Initial plans were to have a premiere and afternoon tea at the church tomorrow.Howeever, coronavirus and the current restrictions meant that that could not take place.The premiere has instead moved online and will take place through the Zoom online video app at pm.The film will also be uploaded to the schoolrsquos YouTube channel.The film includes interviews with three East Lothian residents who grew up during the Second World War, all of whom are involved in Longniddry Parish Church in some way.Louise Marr, an English and film teacher at the secondary school in Prestonpans, said that she had bought a lot of bunting specially for the premiere event to decorate the hall but is thinking of displaying it in her window as part of her own celebrations on the day.She added: ldquoIn our own way, we will still be able to celebrate the end of the Second World War and think about the sacrices made by that generation. ldquoWe ran out of time for the final edit of the film but are very thankful for the work of a former pupil and PL film club member for four years, Alastair Clarke. ldquoAlastair is now studying filmmaking at the University of the Highlands and Islands. title: trademark-hairstyle-set-go-boost-charity
story: Ezra Bragg, , known as Ez, is putting his crowning glory in the hands of his we Jen, , tomorrowin aid of his employer ndash the Bethany Christian Trust which has a launched at pound, emergency appeal.She has admitted to ldquonever using cutters before in her le but is ready to do the head shave in the communal garden of their Inveresk Road home, cheered on by neighbours who will be observing social distancing rules from a balcony.Jen, a psychiatric nurse who has worked in the voluntary sector helping those who suffered from mental health issues, trauma and survivors of abuse in care, has set up a JustGiving page for donations.The couple have already smashed their pound target, with about pound raised.She said: ldquoEz has a big heart and wanted to try and do something to help the trust at this time. title: mekala-osborne-enjoys-outdoors-road-recovery
story: The image was posted on social media by close family friend Davie Martin, on behalf of the family, who described the image as ldquopeaceful.The caption alongside the image read: ldquoYes its our wee warrior Mekala outside in the hospital grounds for the first time in god knows how long.ldquoSo emotional looking at this just trying to imagine what Mekala is just sitting there thinking about. A penny for yer thoughts sweetheart. Your one special lassie.Mum Yvonne said: ldquoI wish I knew what your thoughts are toots. So, so proud of you. Very emotional Mummy tonight.Former Preston Lodge High School pupil Mekala, , was travelling through south-east Asia with a friend last autumn when she phoned home complaining of a sore throat.Over the coming days, and after being given antibiotics and painkillers, her condition worsened and she soon ended up in hospital in an induced coma after being diagnosed with bronchial pneumonia.Mekala, who lives in Wallyford, was then transferred to a hospital in Singapore for further treatment.A fundraising page to allow Yvonne and step-dad Jimmy to be by her bedside attracted donations from across East Lothian and beyond, raising over pound,.Mekala was flown back to the UK in November last year and transferred to the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh for further treatment.She was transferred to the Astley Ainslie at the end of March where she is currently receiving rehab.Mekala is said to be doing really well, she is sitting up and had an assisted shower.Speaking to the Courier last month, Jimmy said: ldquoIt is absolutely amazing.ldquoWhen you look at the first photograph back in September of her lying in hospital in Da Nang [Vietnam] and she had a five per cent chance of survival and then look at her now.ldquoShe is still not the same Mekala we know but she is getting there.ldquoShe has got a big smile on her face and we FaceTime every night to keep in touch.ldquoShe is amazing and she can now move a couple of fingers on each hand.It is hoped Mekala will be home for Christmas.Thank you for reading this story. title: seal-pup-spotters-asked-share-photos
story: Zoologist Donald Malone, a former pupil of Stenton Primary and Dunbar Grammar Schools, will send them to friends at the Sea Mammal Research Unitat the University of St Andrews, who keep databases of seal images and attempt to identy iniduals from them.Mr Malone said: ldquoThis would help gain an idea of the number of both harbour and grey seals around the coast of East Lothian.He added: ldquoThey can also keep a lookout for pups, as harbour seals give birth in June and July and grey seals from September to December. Harbour seal pups shed their whitecoat in the womb before being born and so can be in the water and swim almost straight from birth. Females need to give birth on land though.ldquoGrey seal pups are born with the white lunugo fur and have to stay on land much more until they moult this off around three weeks after giving birth.He saidanyone spots a seal entangled in material such as fishing gear, they should contact British Divers Marine Le Rescuebdmlr.org.uk index.php, which has trained people in East Lothian who will try to capture and free the seal.Mr Malone, who studied zoology at University of Glasgow, has been through this training and has had to aid hundreds of seals all over the world.He was delighted to capture on camera a large group of around  seals, some pregnant, near the Musselburgh lagoons while out for his daily exercise on a cycle from his Edinburgh home.They were hauled out on exposed rocks, just offshore and past the lagoons, heading towards Prestonpans.Mr Malone said: ldquoHarbour seal numbers have actually been in quite drastic decline around Scotland, especially on the east coast, so it was good to see this big group of them.ldquoI am a bit of a fan of seals, having worked on numerous projects on them. This included a project at University of St Andrews where we were looking at the diet of both harbour and grey seals all around Scotland.He now runs his own environmental education organisation, Wildside Nature, which offers workshops and projects to all stages of learners, designed to bring real le science and nature experiences to students.He said: ldquoI use my background as a zoologist to deliver fun, active and engaging workshops on a wide iety of wildle subjects.ldquoI have run workshops in schools and nurseries all over East Lothian including both the Burgh and Loretto RC Primary Schools in Musselburgh and Law Primary School at North Berwick.ldquoI also run sessions at many other schools, nurseries and even with elderly groups all around Scotland and the north of England.Mr Malone is continuing to support childrenrsquos distance learning during the Covid- lockdown.He said: ldquoI have been making activities that people can do at home to help them connect with nature during the current period.ldquoThis has included making bird food from kitchen waste and putting out material that birds will use for nesting material. title: p1-deferrals-u-turn-schools-remain-closed-covid-19
story: Several parents had spoken out in anger after their Primary  deferral funding requests were rejected by the council, which last year had the worst record for approving the applications of any Scottish local authority.This year only two of  applications by parents were approved and of the  refused,  parents appealed.Now the council has said all  cases turned down for funding will be granted the money.However they made it clear the decision was because of the current Covid- pandemic and a review of their policy would be carried out at a later date.One mother told how her children were born two years apart but under the current council policy her youngest son would have had to start P this summer while her oldest, who was born in January, was allowed to defer for a year, was in P.She said: ldquoMy youngest was born at the end of December so they are fully two years apart yet I am not being allowed to defer their start at school and they will be only one year apart in education terms.Current legislation allows parents of children who are born in January and February to automatically receive funding for a delay in starting Primary One until they are five years old.Parents of children born between August and December, who would also start school aged four, can also defer their primary one start for a year but the council can refuse to pay for their nursery care.Last year, East Lothian Council approved  per cent of applications ndash the lowest percentage of any local authority in Scotland. This year the figure fell to less than  per cent.The council also refuses to allow children whose parents opt to keep them home and fund the nursery place themselves to remain in school nurseries.Parents who decide to pay for an additional year of nursery themselves to keep their children out for a year face bills of up to pound, and a hunt for alternative child care places.Another mum who was refused funding said she had initially been supported in her view that her child was too immature to start school by her nursery.But they withdrew that support after pressure from the councilrsquos education department, she said.ldquoThey were told that they couldnrsquot support us because we didnrsquot meet the council policy criteria and withdrew their support, she explained.ldquoOur views meant nothing and the impact on our child meant nothing.And other parents expressed fears that their children were being robbed of nursery experience because they have been in lockdown for some of the vital months they would have had and would have no transition into school.One mum said: Children who start school at -years-old already receive a year less nursery time than those who are older, that has been reduced further by the closure of nurseries.ldquoHow can we ask these young children to go from months at home with their family to suddenly starting primary one with no transition A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoconfirmed they have now agreed to approve all deferral requests for the year ahead.They said: ldquoAs a result of the ongoing closure of schools and nurseries, we have been reviewing applications for deferred entry to P, ahead of session  . Due to the current situation, applications for deferred entry and a further funded year have now been approved. Following the full, national implementation of the expansion of early learning and childcare, we will carry out a review of our wider policy on deferred entry.Thank you for reading this story. title: yacht-club-takes-measures-help-stay-afloat
story: The yachts should have been craned into the harbour at the start of April and the committee had an ldquoanxious pre-season discussion to figure out safe ways to continue activities as the coronavirus crisis started to unfold.After the full lockdown, with the boats still on dry land, members have been using Skype on a near weekly basis to plan how to keep the club thriving for the foreseeable and long-term future.Former commodore Mark McClelland has urged members to take part in an online sailing race game called Virtual Regatta.One club member will be asked to take part in a Virtual Regatta e-championship against players from other Scottish clubs and then go on to a UK-wide competition.While playing the game, Fisherrow Yacht Clubparticipants also take part in a virtual Friday Night Bar get-together, enjoying a tipple in their own homes while connected to other participants through Zoom.One of the biggest losses to the club programme is the start-of-the season event called Discover Sailing, formerly known as Push the Boat Out, which was due to take place this Saturday, May .Inez Visser, club spokesperson, said: ldquoIt should have been an open day for non-members to try sailing and to look around the facilities in the club premises.ldquoDiscover Sailing has been the most important means to recruit new members in the last few years.ldquoFYC hopes to be able to recreate something similar later in the summer while taking into account necessary hygiene requirements.She explained: ldquoMany FYC members can sail their dinghies or yachts solo or with family members so, from that aspect, sailing can resume as soon as is permitted.ldquoIn addition,local members can come to the beach already dressed to go out on the water, this would free up space in the changing facilities for those who travel from further away.ldquoCurrently, the biggest challenge is figuring out a way to crew the club safety and race committee power boats without breach of the contamination guidelines.ldquoHowever, many resourceful solutions have been devised to protect people from contamination so FYC is hopeful a solution for watersports can be found soon.She added: ldquoWhile not sailing, the committee has been looking at research information published by the sailing umbrella body, Royal Yachting Association , which has analysed age demographics and water participation in general in the last few years.ldquoUsing the information from RYA, the club is looking forward to how its current activities and club facilities, especially club-owned boats, can be dferently managed to suit the needs of the next generation of sailors.ldquoThis includes not only Generations X, Y and Z, but also third age sailors, as the research highlighted that sailing is well suited to older people because the physical demands are not as great as many other sports.ldquoAt this time, FYC is ever mindful that the club premises are a resource, not only for the sailing club, but for other users such as the Musselburgh Athletics Club runners, Eskmuthe Rowing Club, sea cadets, Fisherrow Harbour and Seafront Association and the Cooking Club.!In addition, there are one-off users such as the Musselburgh Festival beach ride out guests and British Divers Marine Le Rescue training day volunteers.ldquoAll of the users have had their activities impacted and we hope that, as soon as possible, they too will be able resume.Thank you for reading this story. title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-dirleton-dunbar-east-linton-east-lammermuir-gullane-north-berwick
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at six of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Dirleton Castle.G Laird and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.DirletonTHE Dirleton Area Resilience Teamcontinues to serve its community, with requests to pick up shopping and prescriptions still coming in.It has also launched a new booking system to allow it to better serve its community and protect its volunteers.Its essentials community larder continues to flourish and has seen an entertainment section added.It now stocks books, CDs, DVDs and board games, with sections for both adults and children.Generous donations continue to be made of special food items such as crumbles, bakery treats and soups.DART is working with both the Saltire and Hi Awards, youth volunteer programmes that have allowed the group to include volunteering activities for young people.The Saltire Award is available for young people aged -.It is a nationally credited award that goes towards Scottish Credit and Qualications Framework .Volunteers will be allowed to be a part of DART and help complete requests such as delivering leaflets and fulfilling customer orders.The Hi Awards are for children aged five to . DART will be offering children between these ages at-home volunteering opportunities, such as letter writing and art, which will be sent to those self-isolating and shielding in the village.David Tait, lead co-ordinator for DART, said: ldquoWe now have a great opportunity for the youth in our community to feel part of this amazing organisation.ldquoWith the addition of the awards being nationally recognised and accredited, it was a no-brainer to follow through on this opportunity.ldquoIf any of our youth are interested in the Saltire or Hi Awards, please email your enquiry to Dart.Coordinators@outlook.Contact detailsIf you are in need of assistance, contactDART.coordinators@outlookor call .DunbarDunbarA FRIENDLY voice at the other end of the phone is being offered to people on their own during lockdown.Community resilience volunteers in Dunbar are urging people to get in touch evenit is simply for a chat.The townrsquos volunteers are already offering a range of services, including collecting shopping and prescriptions.In addition, there is also a chance for people to simply talk to someone. George Robertson, a member of the townrsquos community council and chairman of the Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership , stressed the importance of the service.He said: ldquoIt is a really important aspect to the whole thing. I think it will become increasingly important as people get a bit stir crazy.ldquoObviously, a lot of people have friends and family nearby but there are quite a few who do not.ldquoWe need to be conscious that sometimes they are reluctant to ask for help.ldquoWe need to be vigilant for anyone looking for help so we can give a bit of TLC, support, help or a friendly voice on the end of the phone.George has been at the heart of the resilience efforts in the town. Dunbar, along with neighbouring West Barns, has been split into dferent sections, with a lead volunteer in each of the areas.The lead volunteers for the nine clusters ndash Shore and Harbour Group High Street, Parsonspool to Kings Court West End to Countess Road Belhaven and Kirk Park West Barns and the Beveridge Row development Queenrsquos Road and the new housing developments Hallhill, Kellie Road and to the railway line Brodie Road east and north to the railway line and Brodie Road west and north to the railway line ndash have an online meeting each fortnight to checkthere are any issues.George said: ldquoWe are still getting regular requests for shopping, prescriptions and the like.ldquoThere are also a few people who just ring up for a chat.ldquoThat is all ticking along quite nicely.Attention is also turning to how the community copes when lockdown restrictions are relaxed.A number of volunteers willto work as businesses reopen but George was confident that Dunbar and West Barns would continue to be there for people in need.He previously had to draw up a reserve list for volunteers when the coronavirus pandemic started and said there would be enough people to continue to offer support.Contact detailsFor more information, go to Dunbar and District Coronavirus Community Helpers at facebook groups  or Dunbar Community Council at facebook Dunbar CommunityCouncilEast Linton. Picture: Google MapsDunpenderSHOPPING and prescriptions continue to be collected for residents in East Linton and surrounding villages.The Dunpender community resilience team, like many across the county, is offering a iety of services to help people in need during the coronavirus crisis.Judith Priest, chairwoman of the villagersquos community council, said things remained quiet but they were thereanyone was in need of assistance.Contact detailsInformation relating to the coronavirus is available on the Tyninghame Village Hall website ndash tyninghamevillagehall.org.uk ndash as well as on eastlinton.uk.Last month, a flyer was delivered to each home in the area, which offered assistance in terms of shopping, prescriptions or people looking to talk to someone.For more information, call   and  .Stenton.kim traynor and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.East LammermuirTEAMS of volunteers are keeping in touch with each other throughout East Lothian to ensure they are helping people the best they can.Resilience groups have been set up in towns and villages throughout the county during the coronavirus outbreak.Volunteers have come forward to help vulnerable members of the community with any assistance they need.Chris Bruce, chairman of East Lammermuir Community Council, said they were continuing to work together.The community council covers villages including Spott, Stenton, Innerwick and Oldhamstocks.Mr Bruce said: ldquoThere is a pretty good network of email contact, and people follow up with phone callsthere is something particular.ldquoIt is right across East Lothian and is really good.Contact detailsMore information on the help available in the East Lammermuir area is available from the grouprsquos website, eastlammermuircommunitycouncil.org.uk, which also contains a list of the community councillors.Gullane. Picture: Google MapsGullaneA NEW website has been set up to provide people in Gullane with the latest information relating to the coronavirus.The Gullane Resilience Team, made up of volunteers from throughout the village, have been working hard since the outbreak of restrictions due to the global pandemic.Now, a dedicated website has been set up to keep people up-to-date.A spokesman for the villagersquos resilience team said: ldquoThe Gullane Resilience Team have continued to serve the community but have noticed a settling down of demand.ldquoLorna Scott, our co-ordinator, has worked extremely hard and is developing the village hub for the distribution of food, the exchange of DVDs and childrenrsquos games every Tuesday, noon to pm, and Friday, .am to am.ldquoSeveral face shields were donated by Alun Joseph and were passed on to the Gullane Medical Centre and the Muirfield care home.ldquoBoth have reported that they are delighted with them.ldquoA new website, GullaneRT, has been set up which contains all the information regarding how our resources are being deployed and the services that can be provided by the team.Contact detailsFor more information, visit www.gullanert or contact the team on GullaneRteam@gmail or by telephoning  .North Berwick.William Starkey and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.North BerwickNORTH Berwick Day Centre may be closed to its members due to the coronavirus crisis, but it is making sure they are being looked after in their homes.Some  of the day centrersquos  members are receiving sandwich lunches.The centre was established  years ago to improve the quality of le for older people who live independently in and around North Berwick.Normally, members would be brought to the centre by its own specially adapted bus once or twice a week.Now, its nine staff are delivering  lunches, five days a week, and all members are also getting free copies of the East Lothian Courier, thanks to the North Berwick resilience group fund.Care assistant Lisa Robertson said a lot of members were getting their lunch every day and those celebrating birthdays were also getting a special treat.In the past eight weeks, five members have received sweet treats to celebrate their birthdays, with the most recent being a -year-old woman.The Day Centre is also handing out quizzes, games and jigsaws to members, as well as having a chat on doorsteps ndash at a safe distance ndash where possible.Lisa said so far all of the centre members have stayed in good health but they are lonely and missing meeting other people.A team of around  volunteers are contacting members by telephone to have a chat and also find outany other help is needed.Meanwhile, North Berwick Community Councilrsquos resilience group fund is being used to help volunteers get ready-made meals delivered to vulnerable residents in the town three days per week.Community council chair Judy Lockhart has arranged for voluntary organisation Home-Start East Lothian to provide two-course meals at a cost of pound. a day, and is using the fund to subsidise them for people wanting a meal every day of the week.As a result, someone wanting seven meals a week will only have to pay pound.The resilience fund can also offer financial assistance to those who need money to pay for these meals.Contact detailsPeople wishing to sign up for the service should phone the resilience group helpline on   or email communityresilience@northberwickcommunitycouncil.org.ukOr you can visitwww.nbresilience

title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-garvald-gifford-haddington-macmerry-gladsmuir-pencaitland-tranent-elphinstone
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at six of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Garvald.M J Richardson and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.GarvaldCOMMUNITY spirit has been praised in a rural part of East Lothian which is tackling the coronavirus.Garvald and Morham Community Council was one of the first to produce an emergency resilience plan, with the Garvald Emergency Resilience Team also being established.Since then, a leaflet has been hand delivered to each of the properties, with information also put online to keep people up-to-date with what is happening.Penny Short, co-ordinator of the Garvald Emergency Resilience Team, noted there were a number of issues they had to overcome, including the remoteness of some people living in the area.She said: ldquoBefore the coronavirus epidemic and subsequent lockdown hit we had already hand delivered a leaflet to every address in our ward explaining who we were and what the team could do, so that everyone in our area knew who to contactthey needed any help.ldquoOur team members have a WhatsApp Group and we keep in touch through that.ldquoSocial media has been a blessing through this time of social distancing!ldquoOnce lockdown was in place I set up a private Facebook page called Garvald Community which is for residents only.ldquoThis is a safe, supportive place where people can ask for help or assistance and hopefully find helpful advice and information such as messages from the government or information on food deliveries.ldquoInformation on food deliveries is pretty important as Garvald doesnrsquot have any shopsand for people who are self-isolating or shielding these food deliveries are essential.ldquoWe contacted ious food suppliers and co-ordinated delivery days and then passed on the details to the villagers.However, it is not just through social media that the group has reached out to people.An online form, which people can fill in outlining how they need assistance, is available on the villagersquos website.Penny added: ldquoWe are aware of any vulnerable people in our area and we are connected with our residents ndash whether through the Garvald Community Facebook page, the website or the villagersquos Neighbourhood Watch Scheme.ldquoBecause we are pretty remote and used to being cut off in bad weather our community is already pretty resilient and has always been supportive to everyone in the village.ldquoBut our wonderful community spirit has never been more evident than right now as everyone has come together to help each other and provide support with shopping, collecting prescriptions, offers of dog walking and other ways to help each other.ldquoWe have recently launched a group to make face masks for locals and lsquoscrubs bagsrsquo for NHS and care workers.ldquoNot for the first time I am so grateful to stay in Garvald and so proud of our fantastic community."Contact detailsFor more information, go to www.garvald.org.ukGford. Picture: Google MapsGfordGIFFORD volunteers this week trialled a new Soup And A Smile delivery service as they took hot lentil soup, a buttered roll and a fruit scone to households where there are older residents living alone.The plan is to provide lunch one day a week, as well as catch up with residents while observing social distancing rules.Nicola Goddard, from Lanterne Rouge cafeacute, offered her services to support the volunteer activity, which is provided free to the households.A spokesperson for Gford Community Council said: ldquoThe feedback is already very positive both regarding the fabulous quality of the food and the concept.ldquoOur delivery team worked quickly and observed all protocols to deliver the food to households. Wersquore gathering more feedback as we look to provide this on a weekly basis.This week, the team has also been sourcing face coverings for volunteers, to offer them extra confidence when undertaking tasks on behalf of households.Lanterne Rouge donated a supply of lsquobuffsrsquo and local resident and designer Ellie Thomson is making the coverings from her home.The community council said a request for cotton fabric, thread and elastic generated a fantastic response and they are currently trying to source additional elastic.They have also written to Homes For Le Housing Partnership, which oversees social housing flats in the village, after discovering families living there were unable to use their drying greens as gardens.They said: ldquoWe are very lucky in Gford to have a lot of open green space surrounding us.ldquoWe became aware through some tenants in social housing flats that they are unable to use drying greens as garden space for their children.ldquoWe have written to Homes For Le to ask that this situation is revisited so all children can have access to safe outdoor space on their doorstep.ldquoWe received a positive response from the organisation and hope that the guidance can be claried to benefit families in the village.Contact detailsAnyone needing help can contact: Jo Allen, GCC chair, on   or ChairGfordCC@gmail Adam White, GCC vice chair, on   or adamjswhite@outlook Wendy Ferguson, GCC treasurer, on   or wendyferguson.wf@gmail Aniko Schuetz Bradwell, minister, on   or aschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukHaddingtonHaddingtonRESILIENCE volunteers are looking to the future to ensure people continue to receive assistance once lockdown restrictions are relaxed.A squad of volunteers in Haddington have been helping with everything from collecting food and prescriptions to walking dogs and simply providing someone for people to talk to.However, the resilience team is now planning for the future to ensure there are still plenty of volunteers available as lockdown is eased.Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the townrsquos community council, has been at the heart of the resiliency efforts.He said: ldquoWe are now starting to put plans together for coming out of quarantine.ldquoFor a lot of us in the coming weeks, we will be coming out of lockdown but for our elderly residents they will probably still be in lockdown.ldquoWe are starting to plan to make sure everybody is taken care of post lockdown.Currently, many of the volunteers are off their work and able to help throughout the town.However, as businesses reopen and peopleto work, it reduces the amount of free time people have.Chris said it was important to ensure there were still volunteers available to help people who continued to be at home.The group experienced an increase in calls in the last week, with the community council vice-chairman putting it down to many people reaching the end of the month in terms of their wages.He said: ldquoFor some folk it was the end of the month and we were getting an increase in calls about food.ldquoWe have done a few things over the weekend and a couple of things to make sure people have good food, that they are covered and they are not starving themselves.Chris praised the efforts of Our Community Kitchen, who are based in the townrsquos bowling club.The team of volunteers are delivering hot meals to people throughout the town to ensure no-one is going hungry.One other issue Chris pointed to was the increased need in terms of help with gardening.He added: ldquoWith the rain and sunshine over the past week, peoplersquos gardens have started growing.ldquoWe have got in touch with some gardeners, who are going out to help people this week.Contact detailsFor more information, go to www.haddingtoncc.org.uk or call   , between am and pm.Macmerry. Picture: Google MapsMacmerry and GladsmuirTHE Macmerry and Gladsmuir Community Resilience Team are encouraging local residents to continue making pom poms, and are on the lookout for more supplies.In the past two weeks,  craft packs containing equipment necessary to make the pom poms have been distributed, with a number of adults joining in alongside the villagesrsquo children.Stevie Sutherland, one of the resilience co-ordinators, told the Courier that volunteers have put ribbons up along the school gates for people to hang their finished pom poms from.He said: ldquoWersquove had about  packs handed out already and people have started making them.ldquoPeople are encouraged to go along to the school and tie their pom poms to the ribbons.He added: ldquoSince itrsquos started itrsquos become quite colourful and is really nice to see.ldquoThe whole point is to show off community support it will also show and encourage people who are from Macmerry or travelling through that we are supporting frontline workers, whether that be from the NHS, emergency service workers or supermarket staff.ldquoWe are trying to bring back that feel-good factor into the villages, when all we seem to have is bad news.One resident has decided to hang plastic balls of dferent colours outside her house as part of the project.Anyone willing to donate wool, of any quality although double knit is preferred, or anyone needing assistance is asked to call  .Collection or pick up of wool donations can also be arranged.Meanwhile, the resilience team were joined by a couple of new volunteers in the past week, and they will help to deliver the continuing resilience effort.Stevie said the resilience group have put together a contingency plan, should the virusin the future, which will allow the effort to start back up again more quickly and smoothly.He said: ldquoWersquove put a kind of plan in place, forthis all goes away then comes back again.ldquoWe now have an admin system that could be started upneeded.Contact detailsMore information is available on the resilience grouprsquos Facebook and Twitter pages, atfacebook groups   andtwitter MacmerryTeamPencaitland. Picture: Google MapsPencaitlandTHE response from residents in Pencaitland and its surrounding area to an appeal for volunteers has been described as ldquophenomenal by community council chairman Ralph Averbuch.Before lockdown had even been introduced, Pencaitland Community Council was preparing for what was coming with an early call for help.Now they have  volunteers working in a resilience network of support for the communityrsquos most vulnerable families and residents.Ralph said: ldquoOn March , it was already looking like we were approaching unprecedented events in modern times.ldquoIt was still a week away from local schools being closed and social distancing really kicking in however, unprecedented times require unprecedented measures and in Pencaitland and District that involved a call for volunteers.ldquoWe needed to be ready, and quickly, for whatever was coming.ldquoMost calls for community participation in ordinary times generate next to no response.ldquoPeople are busy with their own lives and family work concerns so lsquocommunityrsquo, for most, almost always takes a back seat.ldquoYet, when the call went out for volunteers, the response was nothing short of phenomenal.ldquoWithin  hours we had  people signed up and ready to do whatever needed to be done.ldquoFrom this start, we were able to begin a process of organising volunteers into geographic clusters, each with their own lead co-ordinators.ldquoNothing like this has happened in any of our letimes, yet, when the situation really demanded that people step up and be counted, there was no shortage of volunteers willing and able to help, from people in their teens to those in their s.ldquoWe are now a resilience network of . Had I been asked at the start how many people would come forward Irsquod have thought Irsquod be able to count them on one hand.ldquoThe good news is when itrsquos really important and people know it, there is no shortage of volunteers wanting to help solve our problems.Contact detailsAnyone living in or around the Pencaitland area and seeking assistance, or just wanting to help out, in the first instance can call Community Council chair Ralph on   or email him at covid@pencaitland.org.Additionally, Pencaitland  District Coronavirus Emergency Helpers have a Facebook page ndash facebook groups   ndash where you can get in touchyou want to help with the massive volunteer effort.Tranent. Picture: Google MapsTranent and ElphinstoneTRANENT and Elphinstone Community Council is starting to think about how it will continue delivering its resilience effort once lockdown restrictions start to be relaxed.Member Mike Falconer is the grouprsquos single point of contact and is overseeing the local resilience effort.He told the Courier that, once restrictions begin to lt, people will still need support so the resilience effort will still be needed, something he said could be described as ldquocontingency planning.He said: ldquoWe canrsquot just stop the need is still going to be there.ldquoThe lt of restrictions is going to be gradual [rather than all at once] and we need to think how we are going to manage and maintain the resilience effort and some sort of support.He added that there is not a plan in place, as such, but the community council ldquohas got its eye on it.Meanwhile, it is business as usual and residents who need assistance continue to get the help they need.Mike said: ldquoItrsquos exactly the same and we are carrying on doing what we are doing, delivering food, walking dogs and picking up prescriptions.ldquoWersquove got a routine established and are just carrying on delivering it until we are told to stop.The resilience effort is also helping Fundamental Foods and the Pennypit Trust with food deliveries, as well as assisting with its school hub effort.Contact detailsThose who need assistance can call   or email tranentemergencyresponse@gmail

title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-cockenzie-port-seton-humbie-east-west-saltoun-bolton-longniddry-musselburgh-prestonpans
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port Seton. Picture: Google MapsCockenzie and Port SetonTHE resilience team in Cockenzie  Port Seton continue to help local residents, and more than pound, has been donated to the cause by iniduals and groups since lockdown began.The resilience effort is being led by Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Council, whose chairman, Bryan Hickman, said: ldquoPeople have been so generous and the money is being used to purchase food.Some of the grouprsquos volunteers are asking for donations of wool, to make blankets which will be given to the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh and used for premature babies.To donate items, contact Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Council via email at cockenzieandportseton@hotmail.The resilience group has received a donation from the Walk With Scott Foundation and will deliver craft activity packs alongside its breakfast packs on Wednesdays, helping to keep local residents entertained while at home.To mark VE Day and allow residents to celebrate in lockdown, afternoon tea boxes consisting of items such as sandwiches, scones, cakes and tea will be delivered.Bryan is also keen to get copies of the Courier delivered to elderly and vulnerable residents, as groups in Haddington and North Berwick are doing.The community councilrsquos resilience team are also sending out hot meals and providing food packs to local children who would usually receive free school meals.This is being run from the Port Seton Centre, supported by centre staff.So far,  lunches and  breakfast packs are going out every day.More than , meals are going out to the local community every week.Last week, the centre started receiving a delivery from FareShare, a charity that delivers surplus food from supermarkets to charities and organisations for those in need.Contact detailsAnyone who needs assistance can call the resilience emergency number on  .East Saltoun. Picture: Google MapsLongniddryITrsquoS business as usual for the resilience effort in Longniddry which is being led by the local church and supported by Longniddry Community Council.SheilaJamieson said she is still receiving some queries, such as people with toothache asking the best place to get help.She added that there have not been many shopping requests, as a lot of residents are getting their food through online deliveries.Sheila said: ldquoAlthough we do have quite a lot of older people, we are quite fortunate to have a great community.ldquoVolunteers are also helping their neighbours and friends along with enquiries as they come in.ldquoItrsquos pretty steady and we are just going on as normal.One Longniddry resident has started offering a dogwalking service for those unable to take their pooch on its daily stroll.Those interested should contact Danni Anderson on Facebook.Volunteers are happy to pick up prescriptions, though the local pharmacy offers a delivery service to those aged  and over.Contact detailsThose who need any help or assistance are asked to call Sheila Jamieson on  .Musselburgh. Picture: Google MapsMusselburghRESILIENT Musselburgh has nearly hit the  mark with the number of volunteers who have joined its emergency efforts during the Covid- pandemic.The co-ordinating team have now settled into their new base at the Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre, after their recent move from Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School.Distribution of food and prescriptions to the communities of Musselburgh, Wallyford, Whitecraig and Old Craighall is continuing.Local residents are being supported through referrals from the East Lothian Council Contact Centre and callsto the Resilient Musselburgh dedicated phone number on  .Last week alone,  preschool lunch packs,  meals and  lunches were distributed.Up until last Friday,  soup and sandwich deliveries were made thanks to the Mercat Grill in Whitecraig, which started the initiative on April .Musselburgh Area Partnership, working in partnership with Hickory, started distributing meals on April  and, so far, they have provided  meals to vulnerable people in the local community.Irene Tait, chairperson of Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, who is co-ordinating the volunteer response, said: ldquoIt is so heartening to see the willingness and effort given to the community by the volunteers.ldquoThey have happily gone over and above by uplting and delivering repeat prescriptions from ious locations, including uplts from outside Musselburgh, and are continuing to deliver emergency food packs and pre-school lunches.ldquoWithout them the community response would not happen.Contact detailsThe Resilient Musselburgh dedicated support number is  .Prestonpans. title: former-power-station-site-become-covid-19-testing-centre
story: East Lothian Council has confirmed that the former Cockenzie Power Station site will be opened and operated by the military as part of the UK Governments Covid- testing programme.No date for when it will start operations has been revealed but it is likely to be within the next week as testing is ramped up as part of plans to ease the current lockdown.It will be the first Covid- testing site of its kind in East Lothian, where an assessment centre has also been operating in Musselburgh since the start of April.The site, which was bought by the local authority from ScottishPower and is currently being marketed for economic investment, was offered up as a potential testing location by the council.The unit will be managed and staffed by military personnel, who would be responsible for its safe operation.Military staff will make appropriate use of PPE and no equipment will be left on site whilst the facility is closed.The council said it expects the facility to operate as a self-contained, drive-through facility. People will remain in their vehicle whilst being tested. Initially, it is understood it would operate over two, three-day periods.Tom Reid, the councils head of infrastructure, said: ldquoWe were asked to identy a potentially suitable site for a drive-through, mobile testing facility to be located."The former Cockenzie Power Station site was identied as a site which could be operated safely by military personnel."This facility would enable key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms to undergo testing, which is a vital component of the national response to tackling Covid-."East Lothian Council will continue to play its part and work with partners locally and nationally in dealing with the challenges posed by the emergency.The facility will provide tests for key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms.It is understood key workers and their family members will be eligible for testing.Key workers who are, or have a family member who is, symptomatic, can sign up via thehttps:self-referral.test-for-coronavirus.service.gov.uk portal.Cockenzie power stations famous twin chimneys were demolished in a controlled explosion in September, , two years after it had closed. The power station had opened in .
